subject: Re: OT: IDEA pricing  ( was Re: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices")
msgSnippet: ... Erik, wrong again, I m afraid : even with the support contract, major upgrades are not free (40%/60% of full, no contract price). Notes : - at their
messageBody:
> So the only way the non-support contract way is better is if IntelliJ
> didn't release any new versions during the year. Or if they did but
> charged less for them than they are charging for the 2.6 -> 3.0 upgrade.
> ..
> .. (Though I wasn't complaining about the price; it's worth it to my company.)

Erik,

wrong again, I'm afraid : even with the support contract, major upgrades
are not free (40%/60% of full, no contract price).

Notes :
- at their current pace, they produce about 1 major release/year.
- last year, for Easter, and Christmas, it was possible to buy
personal licenses for 200$. There is much hope they will keep
this good habit.
If they do so, it's just about $200/year to own the very best of
java editor/IDE.
Or $0, if you don't need/wish to upgrade.

- I'm not an IDEA reference, just a happy customer.


People wondering about this version 3.0 stuff can see what it's all
about here :
http://www.intellij.com/idea/new30.jsp


Alain
